articles.title: Astronomers just solved the mystery of “impossible” black holes
articles.summary: New simulations suggest magnetic fields hold the key to forming black holes that defy known mass limits. When powerful magnetic forces act on a collapsing, spinning star, they eject vast amounts of material, creating smaller yet faster-spinning black holes. This process could explain the puzzling GW231123 collision and the existence of “forbidden” black holes.
articles.content:
An extensive series of computer simulations led by astrophysicists at the Flatiron Institute and their collaborators has revealed that magnetic fields are the missing factor behind the creation of black holes whose masses fall within a range once thought impossible.

In 2023, astronomers witnessed a dramatic event: two extraordinarily massive black holes collided roughly 7 billion light-years away. Their immense size and rapid spin defied explanation. According to existing theories, black holes like these simply shouldn't exist.

Researchers from the Flatiron Institute's Center for Computational Astrophysics (CCA) and partner institutions have now uncovered how such cosmic giants might form and eventually collide. By tracing the life cycles of the stars that gave rise to these black holes, the team discovered that magnetic fields -- long overlooked in earlier models -- play a crucial role.

"No one has considered these systems the way we did; previously, astronomers just took a shortcut and neglected the magnetic fields," explains Ore Gottlieb, an astrophysicist at the CCA and lead author of the study, which appears in The Astrophysical Journal Letters. "But once you consider magnetic fields, you can actually explain the origins of this unique event."

The 2023 Collision That Challenged Black Hole Theory

The cosmic crash, now known as GW231123, was detected by the LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA observatories, which measure gravitational waves -- the ripples in space-time produced by massive celestial motions.

At the time of detection, astronomers could not understand how such enormous and fast-spinning black holes had formed. When a massive star exhausts its fuel, it typically collapses and explodes in a supernova, leaving behind a smaller black hole. However, stars within a specific mass range experience an especially violent type of explosion called a pair-instability supernova, which destroys the star completely.

"As a result of these supernovae, we don't expect black holes to form between roughly 70 to 140 times the mass of the sun," Gottlieb says. "So it was puzzling to see black holes with masses inside this gap."

Simulations Reveal a Hidden Force at Work

One possible explanation is that black holes within this "mass gap" form indirectly, through the merger of smaller black holes. But in the case of GW231123, this seemed unlikely. Mergers are typically chaotic, disrupting the spin of the resulting black hole. Yet the two black holes involved in GW231123 were spinning near the speed of light -- the fastest ever observed -- making such a scenario improbable.

To solve the mystery, Gottlieb and his team performed a two-stage simulation. First, they modeled a massive star 250 times the mass of the Sun through its life and death. By the time it exploded as a supernova, it had burned enough fuel to shrink to about 150 solar masses -- just above the theoretical mass gap, leaving behind a black hole.

The next phase introduced magnetic fields into the picture. The model began with the remnants of the supernova: a swirling cloud of stellar debris containing magnetic fields and a newborn black hole at the center. Earlier theories assumed all the remaining material would fall into the black hole, but the new simulations painted a different picture.

How Magnetism Reshapes the Fate of a Collapsing Star

If a collapsing star is not rotating, the surrounding matter falls straight into the black hole. But when a star spins rapidly, that material forms a disk around the black hole, feeding it over time and increasing its spin. Magnetic fields, however, disrupt this process. Their pressure can blast some of the material outward at nearly the speed of light, preventing it from falling in.

This ejection of matter reduces the amount of material the black hole absorbs. The stronger the magnetic fields, the more mass gets expelled. In extreme cases, up to half of the original star's mass can be lost to these outflows. In the team's simulations, this mechanism naturally produced a black hole whose mass fell within the once "forbidden" range.

"We found the presence of rotation and magnetic fields may fundamentally change the post-collapse evolution of the star, making black hole mass potentially significantly lower than the total mass of the collapsing star," Gottlieb says.

Linking Black Hole Mass and Spin

The results point to an intriguing relationship between a black hole's mass and how quickly it spins. Stronger magnetic fields can slow a black hole's rotation and remove more stellar mass, leading to smaller, slower black holes. Weaker fields, on the other hand, allow heavier, faster-spinning ones to form. This pattern could reveal a broader law connecting mass and spin -- a relationship that future observations might confirm.

Currently, no other known black hole systems can test this connection, but astronomers hope upcoming detections will uncover more examples like GW231123.

Bursts of Light From the Darkest Events

The simulations also predict that these magnetic processes produce bursts of gamma rays during black hole formation. Detecting such gamma-ray flashes could help confirm the theory and show how common these massive black holes really are.

If verified, these findings would not only explain an "impossible" collision but also reshape how scientists understand one of the universe's most extreme and fascinating objects.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in astrophysics explaining the formation of previously 'impossible' black holes through magnetic fields, resolving a major cosmic mystery. This discovery has broad implications for our understanding of black holes and the universe, offering a new framework that can be tested by future observations. The story is focused, detailed, and describes a meaningful advancement in space science with potential large-scale impact on the field.
articles.personality_title: Magnetic fields explain the mystery of unusual black holes
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 2023, astronomers observed a rare event where two massive black holes collided far away in space. These black holes were bigger and spun faster than scientists thought possible, creating a puzzle because existing theories said such black holes shouldn’t exist.

**What happened** – Researchers at the Flatiron Institute used computer simulations to study how these black holes formed. They included magnetic fields in their models, which previous studies had ignored. They found that magnetic forces can push away a lot of the star’s material as it collapses, making smaller but faster-spinning black holes. This helped explain the unusual black holes involved in the GW231123 collision.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it solves a long-standing mystery about black holes in a specific mass range thought to be impossible. It also shows a new link between how heavy a black hole is and how fast it spins. Understanding this connection could change how scientists study black holes and the life cycles of stars.

**What's next step** – Scientists hope to find more black holes like those in GW231123 by watching for similar collisions and detecting bursts of gamma rays predicted by the simulations. These observations will test if magnetic fields really shape black holes this way and improve our knowledge of the universe.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Including magnetic fields in star-collapse models explains how “impossible” black holes form, solving a cosmic puzzle and opening new paths for discovery.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les champs magnétiques expliquent le mystère des trous noirs inhabituels
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 2023, des astronomes ont observé un événement rare où deux trous noirs massifs sont entrés en collision très loin dans l’espace. Ces trous noirs étaient plus gros et tournaient plus vite que ce que la science pensait possible, posant un mystère car les théories existantes disaient que ces trous noirs ne pouvaient pas exister.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Institut Flatiron ont utilisé des simulations informatiques pour étudier la formation de ces trous noirs. Ils ont ajouté les champs magnétiques dans leurs modèles, ce que les études précédentes avaient ignoré. Ils ont découvert que les forces magnétiques peuvent repousser une grande partie de la matière de l’étoile en effondrement, créant des trous noirs plus petits mais tournant plus vite. Cela a permis d’expliquer les trous noirs inhabituels impliqués dans la collision GW231123.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle résout un mystère ancien sur les trous noirs dans une plage de masse considérée comme impossible. Elle montre aussi un nouveau lien entre la masse d’un trou noir et sa vitesse de rotation. Comprendre cette relation pourrait changer la façon dont les scientifiques étudient les trous noirs et la vie des étoiles.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques espèrent trouver plus de trous noirs comme ceux de GW231123 en observant des collisions similaires et en détectant des éclairs de rayons gamma prévus par les simulations. Ces observations permettront de vérifier si les champs magnétiques influencent vraiment la formation des trous noirs et d’améliorer notre compréhension de l’univers.

**Une phrase clé** – L’intégration des champs magnétiques dans les modèles d’effondrement stellaire explique la formation des trous noirs « impossibles », résolvant un mystère cosmique et ouvrant de nouvelles voies pour la découverte.
articles.personality_title_es: Los campos magnéticos explican el misterio de los agujeros negros inusuales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2023, los astrónomos observaron un evento raro donde dos agujeros negros enormes chocaron muy lejos en el espacio. Estos agujeros negros eran más grandes y giraban más rápido de lo que se pensaba posible, creando un misterio porque las teorías existentes decían que tales agujeros negros no deberían existir.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores del Instituto Flatiron usaron simulaciones por computadora para estudiar cómo se formaron estos agujeros negros. Incluyeron campos magnéticos en sus modelos, que antes se habían ignorado. Descubrieron que las fuerzas magnéticas pueden expulsar gran parte del material de la estrella mientras colapsa, formando agujeros negros más pequeños pero que giran más rápido. Esto ayudó a explicar los agujeros negros inusuales en la colisión GW231123.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque resuelve un misterio antiguo sobre agujeros negros en un rango de masa que se creía imposible. También muestra una nueva relación entre el peso de un agujero negro y su velocidad de giro. Entender esta conexión podría cambiar cómo los científicos estudian los agujeros negros y el ciclo de vida de las estrellas.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos esperan encontrar más agujeros negros como los de GW231123 observando colisiones similares y detectando ráfagas de rayos gamma que predicen las simulaciones. Estas observaciones probarán si los campos magnéticos realmente moldean los agujeros negros de esta manera y mejorarán nuestro conocimiento del universo.

**Una frase clave** – Incluir campos magnéticos en los modelos de colapso estelar explica cómo se forman los agujeros negros “imposibles”, resolviendo un enigma cósmico y abriendo nuevas vías para el descubrimiento.

articles.title: Caves carved by water on Mars may hold signs of past life
articles.summary: Eight possible cave openings found on the Martian surface look to have once had ancient streams flowing into them, suggesting they are promising places to look for evidence of life
articles.content:
Eight possible cave openings found on the Martian surface look to have once had ancient streams flowing into them, suggesting they are promising places to look for evidence of life

Channels, pits and caves in the Hebrus Valles on Mars may have been carved by ancient flowing water NASA’s Mars Global Surveyor

Caves carved by water that once flowed beneath Mars’s surface could have been ideal for life to thrive, if it once existed on the Red Planet, and they might still preserve traces of it today.

Mars is dotted with holes that look like cave entrances, but these are usually near regions that are suspected to have been volcanically active, which suggests they formed due to processes like underground lava flows, rather than the passage of water.

On Earth, there are thousands of caves formed when water dissoves soluble rock, known as karstic caves. But scientists have yet to find signs of such caves on Mars, despite evidence that the planet was covered in water billions of years ago.

Now, Chunyu Ding at Shenzhen University in China and his colleagues say they have identified eight possible caves that look to have been produced by ancient water flows, rather than volcanic activity. The caves are in the Hebrus Valles, a north-western region containing hundreds of kilometres of valleys and depressions that seem to have been carved out by ancient floods.

These caves have been mapped by previous Mars missions, such as NASA’s Mars Global Surveyor, which orbited Mars from 1997 to 2006. Ding and his team used spectrometry data from that mission to analyse the material around the cave entrances. This shows they are high in carbonate and sulphate minerals, which typically form in the presence of water.

Free newsletter Sign up to Launchpad Bring the galaxy to your inbox every month, with the latest space news, launches and astronomical occurrences from New Scientist’s Leah Crane. Sign up to newsletter

They also found evidence of ancient streams that end near the cave entrances. This is similar to what we see near karstic caves on Earth, says James Baldini at Durham University in the UK. “If you’re looking on a map, you would expect the stream to be on a surface, and then all of a sudden disappear, because the stream water is being pirated by the cave system.”

Daniel Le Corre at the University of Kent, UK, says the mineralogical and geological evidence suggests these could be water caves, but there is nothing about their appearance that looks strikingly different from other caves on Mars. “I’ve spent an inordinate amount of time looking at the Mars global cave catalogue, and these do look very similar to ones that are known to be volcanic in origin,” he says.

If these are water caves, they could be particularly good places to look for life. “In order to have life, you need water and an environment that is sheltered from the intense radioactive bombardment on the surface of Mars,” says Baldini. “Volcanic caves and lava tubes are also reasonable places to look for life, but there’s not necessarily any water involved.”

Martian water caves might also contain stalagmites, the bulbous, protruding columns of rock that are common in karstic caves on Earth, which could act as time capsules for aspects of Mars’s ancient environment, such as its temperature.

But stalagmites can take many thousands of years of constant water flow to form, and even if we manage to send a rover or drone into the caves to sample them, working out when exactly the stalagmites were formed could be extremely difficult, says Baldini.

Journal reference: The Astrophysical Journal Letters DOI: 10.3847/2041-8213/ae0f1c
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery identifying eight possible water-carved caves on Mars, which are promising sites to search for past life. This finding has broad implications for astrobiology and our understanding of Mars's history, offering a meaningful and inspiring advancement in space exploration with potential real-world impact on the search for extraterrestrial life.
articles.personality_title: Scientists discover eight potential water-carved caves on Mars
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Mars has many caves, but most are thought to be formed by volcanic activity, not water. Scientists have been searching for caves made by water because they could hold clues about past life on the planet.

**What happened** – A team led by Chunyu Ding from Shenzhen University found eight possible caves in the Hebrus Valles region of Mars. These caves show signs of ancient water flow, with minerals like carbonate and sulphate around their entrances. They also found evidence of streams that ended near these cave openings.

**Impact** – These caves might be the first discovered on Mars that were carved by water, not lava. If so, they could be great places to look for signs of past life because water is essential for life, and caves offer protection from harsh surface conditions. These caves could also contain stalagmites, which would help scientists learn about Mars’s ancient climate.

**What’s next step** – Future missions could aim to explore these caves directly, using rovers or drones to study their interiors and collect samples. Understanding when stalagmites formed, if present, will be challenging but important for dating Mars’s watery past.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Eight newly identified caves on Mars may have been carved by ancient water, making them promising sites to search for signs of past life and learn about the planet’s history.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques découvrent huit cavernes potentiellement creusées par l’eau sur Mars
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Mars possède de nombreuses cavernes, mais la plupart sont supposées s’être formées par activité volcanique, pas par l’eau. Les scientifiques cherchent des cavernes formées par l’eau car elles pourraient contenir des indices sur une vie passée.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe dirigée par Chunyu Ding de l’Université de Shenzhen a trouvé huit cavernes possibles dans la région de Hebrus Valles sur Mars. Ces cavernes montrent des signes d’anciens écoulements d’eau, avec des minéraux comme le carbonate et le sulfate autour des entrées. Ils ont aussi trouvé des preuves de ruisseaux qui se terminaient près de ces ouvertures.

**Impact** – Ces cavernes pourraient être les premières découvertes sur Mars creusées par l’eau et non par la lave. Si c’est le cas, elles seraient d’excellents endroits pour chercher des traces de vie passée car l’eau est essentielle à la vie, et les cavernes protègent des conditions difficiles à la surface. Elles pourraient aussi contenir des stalagmites, aidant à comprendre le climat ancien de Mars.

**Prochaine étape** – Des missions futures pourraient explorer ces cavernes avec des rovers ou des drones pour étudier leur intérieur et prélever des échantillons. Déterminer l’âge des stalagmites, si elles existent, sera difficile mais important pour dater le passé aquatique de Mars.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Huit cavernes récemment identifiées sur Mars pourraient avoir été creusées par de l’eau ancienne, en faisant des sites prometteurs pour rechercher des signes de vie passée et mieux comprendre l’histoire de la planète.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos descubren ocho posibles cuevas formadas por agua en Marte
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Marte tiene muchas cuevas, pero la mayoría se cree que se formaron por actividad volcánica, no por agua. Los científicos buscan cuevas formadas por agua porque podrían contener pistas sobre vida pasada.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo dirigido por Chunyu Ding de la Universidad de Shenzhen encontró ocho posibles cuevas en la región Hebrus Valles de Marte. Estas cuevas muestran señales de antiguos flujos de agua, con minerales como carbonato y sulfato alrededor de las entradas. También encontraron evidencia de arroyos que terminaban cerca de estas cuevas.

**Impacto** – Estas cuevas podrían ser las primeras descubiertas en Marte formadas por agua y no por lava. Si es así, serían lugares ideales para buscar señales de vida pasada porque el agua es esencial para la vida y las cuevas protegen de las duras condiciones de la superficie. Además, podrían contener estalactitas que ayudarían a estudiar el clima antiguo de Marte.

**Próximo paso** – Futuras misiones podrían explorar estas cuevas con rovers o drones para estudiar su interior y recoger muestras. Determinar cuándo se formaron las estalactitas, si existen, será un reto importante para fechar el pasado acuático de Marte.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Ocho cuevas recién identificadas en Marte podrían haber sido formadas por agua antigua, convirtiéndolas en lugares prometedores para buscar señales de vida pasada y conocer mejor la historia del planeta.
